docs.lead_paragraph: Lawmakers in Buenos Aires granted legal status to gay and lesbian couples, allowing benefits like pensions and hospital visits, a move hailed as a first for the country. The law will cover insurance policies and health benefits covered by the municipal local government only. But it will not permit same-sex couples to adopt children nor marry.

headline.main: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Legal Status For Homosexual Couples

docs.lead_paragraph: Leaders of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union have approved a proposed contract to end the labor dispute that closed West Coast ports this fall. The agreement, approved on Thursday, will now go to a vote among rank-and-file dockworkers. The deal includes no-cost health insurance, a 60 percent increase in pensions and raises that will bring the average longshoreman's annual earnings to around $90,000.

headline.main: National Briefing | West: California: Longshore Pact Advances

docs.lead_paragraph: Cardinal Health Inc., a prescription drug wholesaler in Dublin, Ohio, said yesterday that it would handle an additional $1.8 billion in annual drug sales for the pharmacy-benefits manager Express Scripts Inc. A spokesman for Express Scripts, a St. Louis-based company that manages drug benefit plans for employers and operates a mail-order pharmacy, said that the contract would consolidate its purchases of branded drugs through Cardinal for its mail-order operations. Express Scripts will continue to buy generic drugs from manufacturers.

headline.main: CARDINAL HEALTH GETS $1.8 BILLION DRUG-BUYING CONTRACT

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal judge here halted a proposed settlement between the Cigna Corporation and doctors today, a significant setback to Cigna's planning. The settlement had the preliminary approval of a federal judge in Illinois, but a federal judge in Miami assigned to handle all similar lawsuits stepped in.
docs.abstract: Federal Judge Federico Moreno, assigned to handle all similar suits against Cigna Corp by doctors, halts Illinois settlement that would have let some 600,000 to 700,000 doctors apply for payments of charges that health insurer had automatically cut since 1996; bars Cigna from acting without his permission (S)
docs.snippet: A federal judge here halted a proposed settlement between the Cigna Corporation and doctors today, a significant setback to Cigna's planning.    The settlement had the preliminary approval of a federal judge in Illinois, but a federal judge in Miami...

docs.lead_paragraph: Welfare-to-work programs have moved thousands of women from welfare into jobs, and now many conservative groups that championed those programs are trying to apply them to another problematic population: the hundreds of thousands of men who are released from prisons each year. The organizations, run by religious conservatives and crime-fighting conservatives, believe that the welfare-to-work model -- a mix of tough love and true training -- may reduce recidivism and move many of the roughly 550,000 men released from prison each year nationwide into meaningful employment.

headline.main: From Jail Cell to the Job Market; Conservatives Back Work Programs for Ex-Inmates

docs.abstract: Organizations run by religious and crime-fighting conservatives champion programs to help prisoners being released with job-training, using model established in welfare-to-work programs; America Works has placed more than 300 former prisoners in jobs and is eager to strengthen ties between incarcerated fathers and their children; workshops are offered to help former prisoners in variety of areas, including job interviewing techniques; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In choosing Stephen Friedman as his chief economic adviser, President Bush is getting a Wall Street veteran who is tenacious in pursuit of his ideas but will probably maintain a markedly lower profile than his predecessor, Lawrence B. Lindsey, friends and former colleagues of Mr. Friedman say. Mr. Friedman, 64, is following the path of his former partner, Robert E. Rubin, in leaving Wall Street for Washington. The two were co-chairmen of the Goldman Sachs investment bank from 1990 to 1992, when Mr. Rubin resigned to lead President Bill Clinton's National Economic Council.

headline.main: Man in the News; Economic Adviser From Other Side of the Deficit -- Stephen Friedman

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is clear that the great demand for health care coverage does not generate policies people want at prices they can afford (''Some Tentative First Steps Toward Universal Health Care,'' Business Day, Dec. 7). Even those with coverage struggle to pay the premiums and are often unable to see the doctors they know and trust.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''About Schmidt'' was shown as the opening night selection of this year's New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Stephen Holden's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 27; the full text is online at nytimes.com/movies. The film opens today in Manhattan and Los Angeles. Of all the dramatic transformations Jack Nicholson has undergone in his 44-year screen career, none is more astonishing than his embodiment of a retired, widowed insurance executive from Omaha in Alexander Payne's film ''About Schmidt.'' Plodding in a weary, stiff-legged shuffle, his shoulders bowed, his features half-frozen into the guarded, sunken expression of someone who has devoted decades of thought to actuarial calculation, his character, Warren Schmidt, is a staid Middle American everyman who finds himself adrift at the precarious age of 66.

headline.main: Just an Average Guy Overcoming Obstacles, Helping Keep the Earth Well Salted

docs.abstract: Excerpts from Stephen Holden's September 27 review of movie About Schmidt, directed by Alexander Payne; Jack Nicholson and Kathy Bates star; movie is opening in Manhattan and Los Angeles; photo (M)
